paper_title: Noble-Metal-Free Bi/g-C<sub>3</sub>N<sub>4</sub> Nanohybrids for Efficient Photocatalytic CO<sub>2</sub> Reduction under Simulated Irradiation

catalyst.source: In this study, novel Schottky-junction photocatalysts Bi-metal-deposited g-C 3 N 4 were constructed via a one-step solvothermal process for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction under simulated irradiation.
catalyst.context: In this study, novel Schottky-junction photocatalysts Bi-metal-deposited g-C 3 N 4 were constructed via a one-step solvothermal process for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction under simulated irradiation.The photocatalytic performance illustrated that the nanohybrid catalysts have extreme activity and excellent stability.The maximum CO yield of 3.78 mol h -1 g -1 was reached on the BiCN-0.6 hybrid, which was about 3 times as much as that of pure g-C 3 N 4 .The phase, microstructure, and optical and photoelectrochemical properties were demonstrated by related characterization methods.The improvement mechanism could be ascribed to the enhanced photon absorption capacity and the decreased recombination rate of photoinduced carriers arising from the Schottky barrier in the system.This work may provide a meaningful approach to enhance the photocatalytic activity through a simple and green strategy.

catalyst.context: Detailed explanations involving the characterization instruments, photoelectrochemical tests, and photocatalytic activity evaluation related to this study are given in the Supporting Information. 2.1.Materials.Urea (H 2 NCONH 3 ), bismuth nitrate pentahydrate Bi(NO 3 ) 3 5H 2 O, ethylene glycol (EG), polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP), and nitric acid (HNO 3 ) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Corp., China.All chemicals were of analytically pure grade and used without further purification. 2.2.Synthesis.2.2.1.Synthesis of g-C 3 N 4 .g-C 3 N 4 was synthesized through the polymerization of urea under a high temperature.Appropriate urea was annealed in an alumina crucible at 520 C for 4 h with a ramp of 4 C/min. 45The light yellow powder was acquired after cooling to room temperature naturally. 2.2.2.Synthesis of Bi-g-C 3 N 4 .The nanohybrids were prepared through a one-step solvothermal process.First, 0.364 g of Bi(NO 3 ) 3 5H 2 O was dissolved in 10 mL of HNO 3 solution (1 M) under magnetic stirring, followed by adding 55 mL of EG and stirring for 30 min.Then, 0.6 g of PVP was introduced to the above mixture under vigorous stirring to obtain homogeneous solution.Subsequently, the obtained g-C 3 N 4 powders with different masses (0.10, 0.30, 0.60, 0.80, and 1.00 g) were added to the above mixture and disposed by ultrasonication for 2 h.Then, the admixture was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon liner stainless-steel autoclave and treated at 160 C for 12 h.At last, the sediments were collected by centrifugation, laved with EG and deionized (DI) water several times, and dried in vacuum at 60 C for 10 h to obtain the Bi-g-C 3 N 4 samples.The as-obtained catalysts with different g-C 3 N 4 masses were marked as BiCN-x, where x (x 0.1, 0.3, 0.6, 0.8, and 1.0) represented the mass amounts of g-C 3 N 4 .

catalyst.context: In summary, the non-noble metal Bi was deposited in g-C 3 N 4 through a facile one-step solvothermal approach to fabricate Bi metal/g-C 3 N 4 nanohybrids.The obtained BiCN-0.6 catalyst had the highest activity for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction, with a maximum CO yields of 3.78 mol h -1 g -1 , which was about 2.9 times as high as that of pristine g-C 3 N 4 .The remarkable improvement of the photocatalytic performance is predominantly ascribed as follows: (i) The formation of a Schottky barrier between the metal and semiconductor system could effectively promote the continuous transition of photoinduced charge carriers.(ii) The introduction of a direct plasmonic Bi Scheme 1. Proposed Reaction Mechanism of Photocatalytic CO 2 Reduction on the BiCN Hybrid Energy Fuels metal with SPR effect could promote the light-harvesting capacity.(iii) The larger specific surface area brings more active sites.This work highlights the advantage of metal-semiconductor nanohybrids and provides some meaningful help for exploring g-C 3 N 4 -related catalysts with good photocatalytic efficiency for CO 2 reduction. s Supporting Information The Supporting Information is available free of charge at https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.energyfuels.1c00439.
